title: Twelfth Night; Or, What You Will

scenes.location: An Apartment in the Duke's Palace.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: If music be the food of love, play on, Give me excess of it; that, surfeiting, The appetite may sicken and so die. That strain again, it had a dying fall; O, it came o'er my ear like the sweet sound That breathes upon a bank of violets, Stealing and giving odour. Enough; no more; 'Tis not so sweet now as it was before. O spirit of love, how quick and fresh art thou, That notwithstanding thy capacity Receiveth as the sea, nought enters there, Of what validity and pitch soever, But falls into abatement and low price Even in a minute! So full of shapes is fancy, That it alone is high fantastical.

dialogues.speaker: Curio
dialogues.line: Will you go hunt, my lord?

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: What, Curio?

dialogues.speaker: Curio
dialogues.line: The hart.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Why so I do, the noblest that I have. O, when mine eyes did see Olivia first, Methought she purg'd the air of pestilence; That instant was I turn'd into a hart, And my desires, like fell and cruel hounds, E'er since pursue me. How now? what news from her?

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: So please my lord, I might not be admitted, But from her handmaid do return this answer: The element itself, till seven years' heat, Shall not behold her face at ample view; But like a cloistress she will veiled walk, And water once a day her chamber round With eye-offending brine: all this to season A brother's dead love, which she would keep fresh And lasting in her sad remembrance.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: O, she that hath a heart of that fine frame To pay this debt of love but to a brother, How will she love, when the rich golden shaft Hath kill'd the flock of all affections else That live in her; when liver, brain, and heart, These sovereign thrones, are all supplied and fill'd Her sweet perfections with one self king! Away before me to sweet beds of flowers, Love-thoughts lie rich when canopied with bowers.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: What country, friends, is this?

dialogues.speaker: Captain
dialogues.line: This is Illyria, lady.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: And what should I do in Illyria? My brother he is in Elysium. Perchance he is not drown'd. What think you, sailors?

dialogues.speaker: Captain
dialogues.line: It is perchance that you yourself were sav'd.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: O my poor brother! and so perchance may he be.

dialogues.speaker: Captain
dialogues.line: True, madam; and to comfort you with chance, Assure yourself, after our ship did split, When you, and those poor number sav'd with you, Hung on our driving boat, I saw your brother, Most provident in peril, bind himself, (Courage and hope both teaching him the practice) To a strong mast that liv'd upon the sea; Where, like Arion on the dolphin's back, I saw him hold acquaintance with the waves So long as I could see.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: For saying so, there's gold! Mine own escape unfoldeth to my hope, Whereto thy speech serves for authority, The like of him. Know'st thou this country?

dialogues.speaker: Captain
dialogues.line: Ay, madam, well, for I was bred and born Not three hours' travel from this very place.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: Who governs here?

dialogues.speaker: Captain
dialogues.line: A noble duke, in nature as in name.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: What is his name?

dialogues.speaker: Captain
dialogues.line: Orsino.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: Orsino! I have heard my father name him. He was a bachelor then.

dialogues.speaker: Captain
dialogues.line: And so is now, or was so very late; For but a month ago I went from hence, And then 'twas fresh in murmur, (as, you know, What great ones do, the less will prattle of) That he did seek the love of fair Olivia.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: What's she?

dialogues.speaker: Captain
dialogues.line: A virtuous maid, the daughter of a count That died some twelvemonth since; then leaving her In the protection of his son, her brother, Who shortly also died; for whose dear love They say, she hath abjur'd the company And sight of men.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: O that I served that lady, And might not be delivered to the world, Till I had made mine own occasion mellow, What my estate is.

dialogues.speaker: Captain
dialogues.line: That were hard to compass, Because she will admit no kind of suit, No, not the Duke's.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: There is a fair behaviour in thee, Captain; And though that nature with a beauteous wall Doth oft close in pollution, yet of thee I will believe thou hast a mind that suits With this thy fair and outward character. I pray thee, and I'll pay thee bounteously, Conceal me what I am, and be my aid For such disguise as haply shall become The form of my intent. I'll serve this duke; Thou shalt present me as an eunuch to him. It may be worth thy pains; for I can sing, And speak to him in many sorts of music, That will allow me very worth his service. What else may hap, to time I will commit; Only shape thou thy silence to my wit.

dialogues.speaker: Captain
dialogues.line: Be you his eunuch and your mute I'll be; When my tongue blabs, then let mine eyes not see.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: I thank thee. Lead me on.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: What a plague means my niece to take the death of her brother thus? I am sure care's an enemy to life.

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: By my troth, Sir Toby, you must come in earlier o' nights; your cousin, my lady, takes great exceptions to your ill hours.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Why, let her except, before excepted.

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: Ay, but you must confine yourself within the modest limits of order.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Confine? I'll confine myself no finer than I am. These clothes are good enough to drink in, and so be these boots too; and they be not, let them hang themselves in their own straps.

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: That quaffing and drinking will undo you: I heard my lady talk of it yesterday; and of a foolish knight that you brought in one night here to be her wooer.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Who? Sir Andrew Aguecheek?

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: Ay, he.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: He's as tall a man as any's in Illyria.

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: What's that to th' purpose?

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Why, he has three thousand ducats a year.

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: Ay, but he'll have but a year in all these ducats. He's a very fool, and a prodigal.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Fie, that you'll say so! he plays o' the viol-de-gamboys, and speaks three or four languages word for word without book, and hath all the good gifts of nature.

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: He hath indeed, almost natural: for, besides that he's a fool, he's a great quarreller; and, but that he hath the gift of a coward to allay the gust he hath in quarrelling, 'tis thought among the prudent he would quickly have the gift of a grave.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: By this hand, they are scoundrels and substractors that say so of him. Who are they?

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: They that add, moreover, he's drunk nightly in your company.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: With drinking healths to my niece; I'll drink to her as long as there is a passage in my throat, and drink in Illyria. He's a coward and a coystril that will not drink to my niece till his brains turn o' the toe like a parish top. What, wench! _Castiliano vulgo:_ for here comes Sir Andrew Agueface.

dialogues.speaker: Aguecheek
dialogues.line: Sir Toby Belch! How now, Sir Toby Belch?

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Sweet Sir Andrew!

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: Bless you, fair shrew.

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: And you too, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Accost, Sir Andrew, accost.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: My niece's chamber-maid.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: Good Mistress Accost, I desire better acquaintance.

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: My name is Mary, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: Good Mistress Mary Accost,-

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: You mistake, knight: accost is front her, board her, woo her, assail her.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: By my troth, I would not undertake her in this company. Is that the meaning of accost?

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: Fare you well, gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: And thou let part so, Sir Andrew, would thou mightst never draw sword again.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: And you part so, mistress, I would I might never draw sword again. Fair lady, do you think you have fools in hand?

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: Sir, I have not you by the hand.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: Marry, but you shall have, and here's my hand.

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: Now, sir, thought is free. I pray you, bring your hand to th' buttery bar and let it drink.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: Wherefore, sweetheart? What's your metaphor?

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: It's dry, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: Why, I think so; I am not such an ass but I can keep my hand dry. But what's your jest?

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: A dry jest, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: Are you full of them?

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: Ay, sir, I have them at my fingers' ends: marry, now I let go your hand, I am barren.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: O knight, thou lack'st a cup of canary: When did I see thee so put down?

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: Never in your life, I think, unless you see canary put me down. Methinks sometimes I have no more wit than a Christian or an ordinary man has; but I am a great eater of beef, and I believe that does harm to my wit.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: No question.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: And I thought that, I'd forswear it. I'll ride home tomorrow, Sir Toby.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: _Pourquoy_, my dear knight?

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: What is _pourquoy?_ Do, or not do? I would I had bestowed that time in the tongues that I have in fencing, dancing, and bear-baiting. O, had I but followed the arts!

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Then hadst thou had an excellent head of hair.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: Why, would that have mended my hair?

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Past question; for thou seest it will not curl by nature.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: But it becomes me well enough, does't not?

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Excellent, it hangs like flax on a distaff; and I hope to see a huswife take thee between her legs, and spin it off.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: Faith, I'll home tomorrow, Sir Toby; your niece will not be seen, or if she be, it's four to one she'll none of me; the Count himself here hard by woos her.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: She'll none o' the Count; she'll not match above her degree, neither in estate, years, nor wit; I have heard her swear't. Tut, there's life in't, man.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: I'll stay a month longer. I am a fellow o' the strangest mind i' the world; I delight in masques and revels sometimes altogether.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Art thou good at these kick-shawses, knight?

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: As any man in Illyria, whatsoever he be, under the degree of my betters; and yet I will not compare with an old man.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: What is thy excellence in a galliard, knight?

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: Faith, I can cut a caper.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: And I can cut the mutton to't.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: And I think I have the back-trick simply as strong as any man in Illyria.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Wherefore are these things hid? Wherefore have these gifts a curtain before 'em? Are they like to take dust, like Mistress Mall's picture? Why dost thou not go to church in a galliard, and come home in a coranto? My very walk should be a jig; I would not so much as make water but in a sink-a-pace. What dost thou mean? Is it a world to hide virtues in? I did think, by the excellent constitution of thy leg, it was formed under the star of a galliard.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: Ay, 'tis strong, and it does indifferent well in a dam'd-colour'd stock. Shall we set about some revels?

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: What shall we do else? Were we not born under Taurus?

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: Taurus? That's sides and heart.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: No, sir, it is legs and thighs. Let me see thee caper. Ha, higher: ha, ha, excellent!

scenes.location: A Room in the Duke's Palace.

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: If the duke continue these favours towards you, Cesario, you are like to be much advanced; he hath known you but three days, and already you are no stranger.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: You either fear his humour or my negligence, that you call in question the continuance of his love. Is he inconstant, sir, in his favours?

dialogues.speaker: Valentine
dialogues.line: No, believe me.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: I thank you. Here comes the Count.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Who saw Cesario, ho?

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: On your attendance, my lord, here.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Stand you awhile aloof.-Cesario, Thou know'st no less but all; I have unclasp'd To thee the book even of my secret soul. Therefore, good youth, address thy gait unto her, Be not denied access, stand at her doors, And tell them, there thy fixed foot shall grow Till thou have audience.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: Sure, my noble lord, If she be so abandon'd to her sorrow As it is spoke, she never will admit me.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Be clamorous and leap all civil bounds, Rather than make unprofited return.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: Say I do speak with her, my lord, what then?

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: O then unfold the passion of my love, Surprise her with discourse of my dear faith; It shall become thee well to act my woes; She will attend it better in thy youth, Than in a nuncio's of more grave aspect.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: I think not so, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Dear lad, believe it; For they shall yet belie thy happy years, That say thou art a man: Diana's lip Is not more smooth and rubious; thy small pipe Is as the maiden's organ, shrill and sound, And all is semblative a woman's part. I know thy constellation is right apt For this affair. Some four or five attend him: All, if you will; for I myself am best When least in company. Prosper well in this, And thou shalt live as freely as thy lord, To call his fortunes thine.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: I'll do my best To woo your lady.  Yet, a barful strife! Whoe'er I woo, myself would be his wife.

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: Nay; either tell me where thou hast been, or I will not open my lips so wide as a bristle may enter, in way of thy excuse: my lady will hang thee for thy absence.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Let her hang me: he that is well hanged in this world needs to fear no colours.

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: Make that good.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: He shall see none to fear.

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: A good lenten answer. I can tell thee where that saying was born, of I fear no colours.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Where, good Mistress Mary?

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: In the wars, and that may you be bold to say in your foolery.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Well, God give them wisdom that have it; and those that are fools, let them use their talents.

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: Yet you will be hanged for being so long absent; or to be turned away; is not that as good as a hanging to you?

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Many a good hanging prevents a bad marriage; and for turning away, let summer bear it out.

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: You are resolute then?

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Not so, neither, but I am resolved on two points.

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: That if one break, the other will hold; or if both break, your gaskins fall.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Apt, in good faith, very apt! Well, go thy way; if Sir Toby would leave drinking, thou wert as witty a piece of Eve's flesh as any in Illyria.

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: Peace, you rogue, no more o' that. Here comes my lady: make your excuse wisely, you were best.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Wit, and't be thy will, put me into good fooling! Those wits that think they have thee, do very oft prove fools; and I that am sure I lack thee, may pass for a wise man. For what says Quinapalus? Better a witty fool than a foolish wit. God bless thee, lady!

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Take the fool away.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Do you not hear, fellows? Take away the lady.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Go to, y'are a dry fool; I'll no more of you. Besides, you grow dishonest.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Two faults, madonna, that drink and good counsel will amend: for give the dry fool drink, then is the fool not dry; bid the dishonest man mend himself, if he mend, he is no longer dishonest; if he cannot, let the botcher mend him. Anything that's mended is but patched; virtue that transgresses is but patched with sin, and sin that amends is but patched with virtue. If that this simple syllogism will serve, so; if it will not, what remedy? As there is no true cuckold but calamity, so beauty's a flower. The lady bade take away the fool, therefore, I say again, take her away.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Sir, I bade them take away you.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Misprision in the highest degree! Lady, _cucullus non facit monachum:_ that's as much to say, I wear not motley in my brain. Good madonna, give me leave to prove you a fool.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Can you do it?

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Dexteriously, good madonna.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Make your proof.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: I must catechize you for it, madonna. Good my mouse of virtue, answer me.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Well sir, for want of other idleness, I'll 'bide your proof.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Good madonna, why mourn'st thou?

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Good fool, for my brother's death.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: I think his soul is in hell, madonna.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: I know his soul is in heaven, fool.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: The more fool you, madonna, to mourn for your brother's soul being in heaven. Take away the fool, gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: What think you of this fool, Malvolio? doth he not mend?

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: Yes; and shall do, till the pangs of death shake him. Infirmity, that decays the wise, doth ever make the better fool.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: God send you, sir, a speedy infirmity, for the better increasing your folly! Sir Toby will be sworn that I am no fox; but he will not pass his word for twopence that you are no fool.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: How say you to that, Malvolio?

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: I marvel your ladyship takes delight in such a barren rascal; I saw him put down the other day with an ordinary fool, that has no more brain than a stone. Look you now, he's out of his guard already; unless you laugh and minister occasion to him, he is gagged. I protest I take these wise men, that crow so at these set kind of fools, no better than the fools' zanies.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: O, you are sick of self-love, Malvolio, and taste with a distempered appetite. To be generous, guiltless, and of free disposition, is to take those things for bird-bolts that you deem cannon bullets. There is no slander in an allowed fool, though he do nothing but rail; nor no railing in a known discreet man, though he do nothing but reprove.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Now Mercury endue thee with leasing, for thou speak'st well of fools!

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: Madam, there is at the gate a young gentleman much desires to speak with you.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: From the Count Orsino, is it?

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: I know not, madam; 'tis a fair young man, and well attended.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Who of my people hold him in delay?

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: Sir Toby, madam, your kinsman.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Fetch him off, I pray you; he speaks nothing but madman. Fie on him! Go you, Malvolio. If it be a suit from the Count, I am sick, or not at home. What you will, to dismiss it. Now you see, sir, how your fooling grows old, and people dislike it.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Thou hast spoke for us, madonna, as if thy eldest son should be a fool: whose skull Jove cram with brains, for here he comes, one of thy kin has a most weak _pia mater_.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: By mine honour, half drunk. What is he at the gate, cousin?

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: A gentleman.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: A gentleman? What gentleman?

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: 'Tis a gentleman here. A plague o' these pickle-herrings! How now, sot?

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Good Sir Toby.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Cousin, cousin, how have you come so early by this lethargy?

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Lechery! I defy lechery. There's one at the gate.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Ay, marry, what is he?

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Let him be the devil an he will, I care not: give me faith, say I. Well, it's all one.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: What's a drunken man like, fool?

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Like a drowned man, a fool, and a madman: one draught above heat makes him a fool, the second mads him, and a third drowns him.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Go thou and seek the coroner, and let him sit o' my coz; for he's in the third degree of drink; he's drowned. Go, look after him.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: He is but mad yet, madonna; and the fool shall look to the madman.

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: Madam, yond young fellow swears he will speak with you. I told him you were sick; he takes on him to understand so much, and therefore comes to speak with you. I told him you were asleep; he seems to have a foreknowledge of that too, and therefore comes to speak with you. What is to be said to him, lady? He's fortified against any denial.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Tell him, he shall not speak with me.

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: Has been told so; and he says he'll stand at your door like a sheriff's post, and be the supporter of a bench, but he'll speak with you.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: What kind o' man is he?

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: Why, of mankind.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: What manner of man?

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: Of very ill manner; he'll speak with you, will you or no.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Of what personage and years is he?

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: Not yet old enough for a man, nor young enough for a boy; as a squash is before 'tis a peascod, or a codling, when 'tis almost an apple. 'Tis with him in standing water, between boy and man. He is very well-favoured, and he speaks very shrewishly. One would think his mother's milk were scarce out of him.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Let him approach. Call in my gentlewoman.

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: Gentlewoman, my lady calls.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Give me my veil; come, throw it o'er my face. We'll once more hear Orsino's embassy.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: The honourable lady of the house, which is she?

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Speak to me; I shall answer for her. Your will?

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: Most radiant, exquisite, and unmatchable beauty,-I pray you, tell me if this be the lady of the house, for I never saw her. I would be loath to cast away my speech; for besides that it is excellently well penned, I have taken great pains to con it. Good beauties, let me sustain no scorn; I am very comptible, even to the least sinister usage.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Whence came you, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: I can say little more than I have studied, and that question's out of my part. Good gentle one, give me modest assurance, if you be the lady of the house, that I may proceed in my speech.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Are you a comedian?

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: No, my profound heart: and yet, by the very fangs of malice I swear, I am not that I play. Are you the lady of the house?

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: If I do not usurp myself, I am.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: Most certain, if you are she, you do usurp yourself; for what is yours to bestow is not yours to reserve. But this is from my commission. I will on with my speech in your praise, and then show you the heart of my message.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Come to what is important in't: I forgive you the praise.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: Alas, I took great pains to study it, and 'tis poetical.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: It is the more like to be feigned; I pray you keep it in. I heard you were saucy at my gates; and allowed your approach, rather to wonder at you than to hear you. If you be mad, be gone; if you have reason, be brief: 'tis not that time of moon with me to make one in so skipping a dialogue.

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: Will you hoist sail, sir? Here lies your way.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: No, good swabber, I am to hull here a little longer. Some mollification for your giant, sweet lady. Tell me your mind. I am a messenger.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Sure, you have some hideous matter to deliver, when the courtesy of it is so fearful. Speak your office.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: It alone concerns your ear. I bring no overture of war, no taxation of homage; I hold the olive in my hand: my words are as full of peace as matter.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Yet you began rudely. What are you? What would you?

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: The rudeness that hath appeared in me have I learned from my entertainment. What I am and what I would are as secret as maidenhead: to your ears, divinity; to any other's, profanation.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Give us the place alone: we will hear this divinity. Now, sir, what is your text?

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: Most sweet lady-

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: A comfortable doctrine, and much may be said of it. Where lies your text?

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: In Orsino's bosom.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: In his bosom? In what chapter of his bosom?

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: To answer by the method, in the first of his heart.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: O, I have read it; it is heresy. Have you no more to say?

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: Good madam, let me see your face.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Have you any commission from your lord to negotiate with my face? You are now out of your text: but we will draw the curtain and show you the picture.  Look you, sir, such a one I was this present. Is't not well done?

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: Excellently done, if God did all.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: 'Tis in grain, sir; 'twill endure wind and weather.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: 'Tis beauty truly blent, whose red and white Nature's own sweet and cunning hand laid on. Lady, you are the cruel'st she alive If you will lead these graces to the grave, And leave the world no copy.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: O, sir, I will not be so hard-hearted; I will give out divers schedules of my beauty. It shall be inventoried and every particle and utensil labelled to my will: as, item, two lips indifferent red; item, two grey eyes with lids to them; item, one neck, one chin, and so forth. Were you sent hither to praise me?

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: I see you what you are, you are too proud; But, if you were the devil, you are fair. My lord and master loves you. O, such love Could be but recompens'd though you were crown'd The nonpareil of beauty!

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: How does he love me?

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: With adorations, fertile tears, With groans that thunder love, with sighs of fire.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Your lord does know my mind, I cannot love him: Yet I suppose him virtuous, know him noble, Of great estate, of fresh and stainless youth; In voices well divulg'd, free, learn'd, and valiant, And in dimension and the shape of nature, A gracious person. But yet I cannot love him. He might have took his answer long ago.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: If I did love you in my master's flame, With such a suff'ring, such a deadly life, In your denial I would find no sense, I would not understand it.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Why, what would you?

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: Make me a willow cabin at your gate, And call upon my soul within the house; Write loyal cantons of contemned love, And sing them loud even in the dead of night; Hallow your name to the reverberate hills, And make the babbling gossip of the air Cry out Olivia! O, you should not rest Between the elements of air and earth, But you should pity me.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: You might do much. What is your parentage?

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: Above my fortunes, yet my state is well: I am a gentleman.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Get you to your lord; I cannot love him: let him send no more, Unless, perchance, you come to me again, To tell me how he takes it. Fare you well: I thank you for your pains: spend this for me.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: I am no fee'd post, lady; keep your purse; My master, not myself, lacks recompense. Love make his heart of flint that you shall love, And let your fervour like my master's be Plac'd in contempt. Farewell, fair cruelty.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: What is your parentage? ‘Above my fortunes, yet my state is well: I am a gentleman.' I'll be sworn thou art; Thy tongue, thy face, thy limbs, actions, and spirit, Do give thee five-fold blazon. Not too fast: soft, soft! Unless the master were the man. How now? Even so quickly may one catch the plague? Methinks I feel this youth's perfections With an invisible and subtle stealth To creep in at mine eyes. Well, let it be. What ho, Malvolio!

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: Here, madam, at your service.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Run after that same peevish messenger The County's man: he left this ring behind him, Would I or not; tell him, I'll none of it. Desire him not to flatter with his lord, Nor hold him up with hopes; I am not for him. If that the youth will come this way tomorrow, I'll give him reasons for't. Hie thee, Malvolio.

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: Madam, I will.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: I do I know not what, and fear to find Mine eye too great a flatterer for my mind. Fate, show thy force, ourselves we do not owe. What is decreed must be; and be this so!

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: Will you stay no longer? Nor will you not that I go with you?

dialogues.speaker: Sebastian
dialogues.line: By your patience, no; my stars shine darkly over me; the malignancy of my fate might perhaps distemper yours; therefore I shall crave of you your leave that I may bear my evils alone. It were a bad recompense for your love, to lay any of them on you.

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: Let me know of you whither you are bound.

dialogues.speaker: Sebastian
dialogues.line: No, sooth, sir; my determinate voyage is mere extravagancy. But I perceive in you so excellent a touch of modesty, that you will not extort from me what I am willing to keep in. Therefore it charges me in manners the rather to express myself. You must know of me then, Antonio, my name is Sebastian, which I called Roderigo; my father was that Sebastian of Messaline whom I know you have heard of. He left behind him myself and a sister, both born in an hour. If the heavens had been pleased, would we had so ended! But you, sir, altered that, for some hour before you took me from the breach of the sea was my sister drowned.

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: Alas the day!

dialogues.speaker: Sebastian
dialogues.line: A lady, sir, though it was said she much resembled me, was yet of many accounted beautiful. But though I could not with such estimable wonder overfar believe that, yet thus far I will boldly publish her, she bore a mind that envy could not but call fair. She is drowned already, sir, with salt water, though I seem to drown her remembrance again with more.

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: Pardon me, sir, your bad entertainment.

dialogues.speaker: Sebastian
dialogues.line: O good Antonio, forgive me your trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: If you will not murder me for my love, let me be your servant.

dialogues.speaker: Sebastian
dialogues.line: If you will not undo what you have done, that is, kill him whom you have recovered, desire it not. Fare ye well at once; my bosom is full of kindness, and I am yet so near the manners of my mother, that upon the least occasion more, mine eyes will tell tales of me. I am bound to the Count Orsino's court: farewell.

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: The gentleness of all the gods go with thee! I have many enemies in Orsino's court, Else would I very shortly see thee there: But come what may, I do adore thee so, That danger shall seem sport, and I will go.

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: Were you not even now with the Countess Olivia?

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: Even now, sir; on a moderate pace I have since arrived but hither.

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: She returns this ring to you, sir; you might have saved me my pains, to have taken it away yourself. She adds, moreover, that you should put your lord into a desperate assurance she will none of him. And one thing more, that you be never so hardy to come again in his affairs, unless it be to report your lord's taking of this. Receive it so.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: She took the ring of me: I'll none of it.

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: Come sir, you peevishly threw it to her; and her will is it should be so returned. If it be worth stooping for, there it lies in your eye; if not, be it his that finds it.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: I left no ring with her; what means this lady? Fortune forbid my outside have not charm'd her! She made good view of me, indeed, so much, That methought her eyes had lost her tongue, For she did speak in starts distractedly. She loves me, sure, the cunning of her passion Invites me in this churlish messenger. None of my lord's ring? Why, he sent her none. I am the man; if it be so, as 'tis, Poor lady, she were better love a dream. Disguise, I see thou art a wickedness Wherein the pregnant enemy does much. How easy is it for the proper false In women's waxen hearts to set their forms! Alas, our frailty is the cause, not we, For such as we are made of, such we be. How will this fadge? My master loves her dearly, And I, poor monster, fond as much on him, And she, mistaken, seems to dote on me. What will become of this? As I am man, My state is desperate for my master's love; As I am woman (now alas the day!) What thriftless sighs shall poor Olivia breathe! O time, thou must untangle this, not I, It is too hard a knot for me t'untie!

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Approach, Sir Andrew; not to be abed after midnight, is to be up betimes; and _diluculo surgere_, thou know'st.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: Nay, by my troth, I know not; but I know to be up late is to be up late.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: A false conclusion; I hate it as an unfilled can. To be up after midnight, and to go to bed then is early: so that to go to bed after midnight is to go to bed betimes. Does not our lives consist of the four elements?

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: Faith, so they say, but I think it rather consists of eating and drinking.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Th'art a scholar; let us therefore eat and drink. Marian, I say! a stoup of wine.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: Here comes the fool, i' faith.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: How now, my hearts? Did you never see the picture of "we three"?

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Welcome, ass. Now let's have a catch.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: By my troth, the fool has an excellent breast. I had rather than forty shillings I had such a leg, and so sweet a breath to sing, as the fool has. In sooth, thou wast in very gracious fooling last night when thou spok'st of Pigrogromitus, of the Vapians passing the equinoctial of Queubus; 'twas very good, i' faith. I sent thee sixpence for thy leman. Hadst it?

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: I did impeticos thy gratillity; for Malvolio's nose is no whipstock. My lady has a white hand, and the Myrmidons are no bottle-ale houses.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: Excellent! Why, this is the best fooling, when all is done. Now, a song.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Come on, there is sixpence for you. Let's have a song.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: There's a testril of me too: if one knight give a-

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Would you have a love-song, or a song of good life?

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: A love-song, a love-song.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: Ay, ay. I care not for good life. CLOWN.  _O mistress mine, where are you roaming? O stay and hear, your true love's coming, That can sing both high and low. Trip no further, pretty sweeting. Journeys end in lovers meeting, Every wise man's son doth know._

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: Excellent good, i' faith.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Good, good.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: _What is love? 'Tis not hereafter, Present mirth hath present laughter. What's to come is still unsure. In delay there lies no plenty, Then come kiss me, sweet and twenty. Youth's a stuff will not endure._

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: A mellifluous voice, as I am true knight.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: A contagious breath.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: Very sweet and contagious, i' faith.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: To hear by the nose, it is dulcet in contagion. But shall we make the welkin dance indeed? Shall we rouse the night-owl in a catch that will draw three souls out of one weaver? Shall we do that?

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: And you love me, let's do't: I am dog at a catch.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: By'r lady, sir, and some dogs will catch well.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: Most certain. Let our catch be, "Thou knave."

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: "Hold thy peace, thou knave" knight? I shall be constrain'd in't to call thee knave, knight.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: 'Tis not the first time I have constrained one to call me knave. Begin, fool; it begins "Hold thy peace."

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: I shall never begin if I hold my peace.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: Good, i' faith! Come, begin.

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: What a caterwauling do you keep here! If my lady have not called up her steward Malvolio, and bid him turn you out of doors, never trust me.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: My lady's a Cataian, we are politicians, Malvolio's a Peg-a-Ramsey, and  _Three merry men be we._ Am not I consanguineous? Am I not of her blood? Tilly-vally! "Lady"! _There dwelt a man in Babylon, Lady, Lady._

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Beshrew me, the knight's in admirable fooling.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: Ay, he does well enough if he be disposed, and so do I too; he does it with a better grace, but I do it more natural.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: _O' the twelfth day of December-_

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: For the love o' God, peace!

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: My masters, are you mad? Or what are you? Have you no wit, manners, nor honesty, but to gabble like tinkers at this time of night? Do ye make an ale-house of my lady's house, that ye squeak out your coziers' catches without any mitigation or remorse of voice? Is there no respect of place, persons, nor time, in you?

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: We did keep time, sir, in our catches. Sneck up!

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: Sir Toby, I must be round with you. My lady bade me tell you that, though she harbours you as her kinsman she's nothing allied to your disorders. If you can separate yourself and your misdemeanours, you are welcome to the house; if not, and it would please you to take leave of her, she is very willing to bid you farewell.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: _Farewell, dear heart, since I must needs be gone._

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: Nay, good Sir Toby.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: _His eyes do show his days are almost done._

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: Is't even so?

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: _But I will never die._

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: _Sir Toby, there you lie._

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: This is much credit to you.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: _Shall I bid him go?_

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: _What and if you do?_

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: _Shall I bid him go, and spare not?_

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: _O, no, no, no, no, you dare not._

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Out o' tune? sir, ye lie. Art any more than a steward? Dost thou think, because thou art virtuous, there shall be no more cakes and ale?

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Yes, by Saint Anne, and ginger shall be hot i' the mouth too.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Th'art i' the right. Go, sir, rub your chain with crumbs. A stoup of wine, Maria!

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: Mistress Mary, if you prized my lady's favour at anything more than contempt, you would not give means for this uncivil rule; she shall know of it, by this hand.

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: Go shake your ears.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: 'Twere as good a deed as to drink when a man's a-hungry, to challenge him the field, and then to break promise with him and make a fool of him.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Do't, knight. I'll write thee a challenge; or I'll deliver thy indignation to him by word of mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: Sweet Sir Toby, be patient for tonight. Since the youth of the Count's was today with my lady, she is much out of quiet. For Monsieur Malvolio, let me alone with him. If I do not gull him into a nayword, and make him a common recreation, do not think I have wit enough to lie straight in my bed. I know I can do it.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Possess us, possess us, tell us something of him.

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: Marry, sir, sometimes he is a kind of Puritan.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: O, if I thought that, I'd beat him like a dog.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: What, for being a Puritan? Thy exquisite reason, dear knight?

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: I have no exquisite reason for't, but I have reason good enough.

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: The devil a Puritan that he is, or anything constantly but a time-pleaser, an affectioned ass that cons state without book and utters it by great swarths; the best persuaded of himself, so crammed (as he thinks) with excellencies, that it is his grounds of faith that all that look on him love him. And on that vice in him will my revenge find notable cause to work.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: What wilt thou do?

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: I will drop in his way some obscure epistles of love, wherein by the colour of his beard, the shape of his leg, the manner of his gait, the expressure of his eye, forehead, and complexion, he shall find himself most feelingly personated. I can write very like my lady your niece; on a forgotten matter we can hardly make distinction of our hands.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Excellent! I smell a device.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: I have't in my nose too.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: He shall think, by the letters that thou wilt drop, that they come from my niece, and that she is in love with him.

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: My purpose is indeed a horse of that colour.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: And your horse now would make him an ass.

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: Ass, I doubt not.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: O 'twill be admirable!

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: Sport royal, I warrant you. I know my physic will work with him. I will plant you two, and let the fool make a third, where he shall find the letter. Observe his construction of it. For this night, to bed, and dream on the event. Farewell.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Good night, Penthesilea.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: Before me, she's a good wench.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: She's a beagle true bred, and one that adores me. What o' that?

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: I was adored once too.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Let's to bed, knight. Thou hadst need send for more money.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: If I cannot recover your niece, I am a foul way out.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Send for money, knight; if thou hast her not i' th' end, call me cut.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: If I do not, never trust me, take it how you will.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Come, come, I'll go burn some sack, 'tis too late to go to bed now. Come, knight, come, knight.

scenes.location: A Room in the Duke's Palace.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Give me some music. Now, good morrow, friends. Now, good Cesario, but that piece of song, That old and antique song we heard last night; Methought it did relieve my passion much, More than light airs and recollected terms Of these most brisk and giddy-paced times. Come, but one verse.

dialogues.speaker: Curio
dialogues.line: He is not here, so please your lordship, that should sing it.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Who was it?

dialogues.speaker: Curio
dialogues.line: Feste, the jester, my lord, a fool that the Lady Olivia's father took much delight in. He is about the house.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Seek him out, and play the tune the while. Come hither, boy. If ever thou shalt love, In the sweet pangs of it remember me: For such as I am, all true lovers are, Unstaid and skittish in all motions else, Save in the constant image of the creature That is belov'd. How dost thou like this tune?

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: It gives a very echo to the seat Where love is throned.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Thou dost speak masterly. My life upon't, young though thou art, thine eye Hath stayed upon some favour that it loves. Hath it not, boy?

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: A little, by your favour.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: What kind of woman is't?

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: Of your complexion.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: She is not worth thee, then. What years, i' faith?

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: About your years, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Too old, by heaven! Let still the woman take An elder than herself; so wears she to him, So sways she level in her husband's heart. For, boy, however we do praise ourselves, Our fancies are more giddy and unfirm, More longing, wavering, sooner lost and worn, Than women's are.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: I think it well, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Then let thy love be younger than thyself, Or thy affection cannot hold the bent: For women are as roses, whose fair flower Being once display'd, doth fall that very hour.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: And so they are: alas, that they are so; To die, even when they to perfection grow!

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: O, fellow, come, the song we had last night. Mark it, Cesario, it is old and plain; The spinsters and the knitters in the sun, And the free maids, that weave their thread with bones Do use to chant it: it is silly sooth, And dallies with the innocence of love Like the old age.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Are you ready, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Ay; prithee, sing. The Clown's song. _    Come away, come away, death. And in sad cypress let me be laid. Fly away, fly away, breath; I am slain by a fair cruel maid. My shroud of white, stuck all with yew, O, prepare it! My part of death no one so true Did share it._ _    Not a flower, not a flower sweet, On my black coffin let there be strown: Not a friend, not a friend greet My poor corpse where my bones shall be thrown: A thousand thousand sighs to save, Lay me, O, where Sad true lover never find my grave, To weep there._

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: There's for thy pains.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: No pains, sir; I take pleasure in singing, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: I'll pay thy pleasure, then.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Truly sir, and pleasure will be paid one time or another.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Give me now leave to leave thee.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Now the melancholy god protect thee, and the tailor make thy doublet of changeable taffeta, for thy mind is a very opal. I would have men of such constancy put to sea, that their business might be everything, and their intent everywhere, for that's it that always makes a good voyage of nothing. Farewell.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Let all the rest give place. Once more, Cesario, Get thee to yond same sovereign cruelty. Tell her my love, more noble than the world, Prizes not quantity of dirty lands; The parts that fortune hath bestow'd upon her, Tell her I hold as giddily as fortune; But 'tis that miracle and queen of gems That nature pranks her in attracts my soul.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: But if she cannot love you, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: I cannot be so answer'd.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: Sooth, but you must. Say that some lady, as perhaps there is, Hath for your love as great a pang of heart As you have for Olivia: you cannot love her; You tell her so. Must she not then be answer'd?

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: There is no woman's sides Can bide the beating of so strong a passion As love doth give my heart: no woman's heart So big, to hold so much; they lack retention. Alas, their love may be called appetite, No motion of the liver, but the palate, That suffer surfeit, cloyment, and revolt; But mine is all as hungry as the sea, And can digest as much. Make no compare Between that love a woman can bear me And that I owe Olivia.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: Ay, but I know-

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: What dost thou know?

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: Too well what love women to men may owe. In faith, they are as true of heart as we. My father had a daughter loved a man, As it might be perhaps, were I a woman, I should your lordship.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: And what's her history?

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: A blank, my lord. She never told her love, But let concealment, like a worm i' th' bud, Feed on her damask cheek: she pined in thought, And with a green and yellow melancholy She sat like patience on a monument, Smiling at grief. Was not this love, indeed? We men may say more, swear more, but indeed, Our shows are more than will; for still we prove Much in our vows, but little in our love.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: But died thy sister of her love, my boy?

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: I am all the daughters of my father's house, And all the brothers too: and yet I know not. Sir, shall I to this lady?

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Ay, that's the theme. To her in haste. Give her this jewel; say My love can give no place, bide no denay.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Come thy ways, Signior Fabian.

dialogues.speaker: Fabian
dialogues.line: Nay, I'll come. If I lose a scruple of this sport, let me be boiled to death with melancholy.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Wouldst thou not be glad to have the niggardly rascally sheep-biter come by some notable shame?

dialogues.speaker: Fabian
dialogues.line: I would exult, man. You know he brought me out o' favour with my lady about a bear-baiting here.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: To anger him we'll have the bear again, and we will fool him black and blue, shall we not, Sir Andrew?

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: And we do not, it is pity of our lives.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Here comes the little villain. How now, my metal of India?

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: Get ye all three into the box-tree. Malvolio's coming down this walk; he has been yonder i' the sun practising behaviour to his own shadow this half hour: observe him, for the love of mockery; for I know this letter will make a contemplative idiot of him. Close, in the name of jesting!  Lie thou there;  for here comes the trout that must be caught with tickling.

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: 'Tis but fortune, all is fortune. Maria once told me she did affect me, and I have heard herself come thus near, that should she fancy, it should be one of my complexion. Besides, she uses me with a more exalted respect than anyone else that follows her. What should I think on't?

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Here's an overweening rogue!

dialogues.speaker: Fabian
dialogues.line: O, peace! Contemplation makes a rare turkey-cock of him; how he jets under his advanced plumes!

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: 'Slight, I could so beat the rogue!

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Peace, I say.

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: To be Count Malvolio.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Ah, rogue!

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: Pistol him, pistol him.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Peace, peace.

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: There is example for't. The lady of the Strachy married the yeoman of the wardrobe.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: Fie on him, Jezebel!

dialogues.speaker: Fabian
dialogues.line: O, peace! now he's deeply in; look how imagination blows him.

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: Having been three months married to her, sitting in my state-

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: O for a stone-bow to hit him in the eye!

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: Calling my officers about me, in my branched velvet gown; having come from a day-bed, where I have left Olivia sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Fire and brimstone!

dialogues.speaker: Fabian
dialogues.line: O, peace, peace.

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: And then to have the humour of state; and after a demure travel of regard, telling them I know my place as I would they should do theirs, to ask for my kinsman Toby.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Bolts and shackles!

dialogues.speaker: Fabian
dialogues.line: O, peace, peace, peace! Now, now.

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: Seven of my people, with an obedient start, make out for him. I frown the while, and perchance wind up my watch, or play with some rich jewel. Toby approaches; curtsies there to me-

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Shall this fellow live?

dialogues.speaker: Fabian
dialogues.line: Though our silence be drawn from us with cars, yet peace!

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: I extend my hand to him thus, quenching my familiar smile with an austere regard of control-

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: And does not Toby take you a blow o' the lips then?

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: Saying ‘Cousin Toby, my fortunes having cast me on your niece, give me this prerogative of speech-'

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: What, what?

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: ‘You must amend your drunkenness.'

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Out, scab!

dialogues.speaker: Fabian
dialogues.line: Nay, patience, or we break the sinews of our plot.

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: ‘Besides, you waste the treasure of your time with a foolish knight-'

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: That's me, I warrant you.

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: ‘One Sir Andrew.'

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: I knew 'twas I, for many do call me fool.

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: What employment have we here?

dialogues.speaker: Fabian
dialogues.line: Now is the woodcock near the gin.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: O, peace! And the spirit of humours intimate reading aloud to him!

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: By my life, this is my lady's hand: these be her very C's, her U's, and her T's, and thus makes she her great P's. It is in contempt of question, her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: Her C's, her U's, and her T's. Why that?

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: _To the unknown beloved, this, and my good wishes._ Her very phrases! By your leave, wax. Soft! and the impressure her Lucrece, with which she uses to seal: 'tis my lady. To whom should this be?

dialogues.speaker: Fabian
dialogues.line: This wins him, liver and all.

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: _    Jove knows I love, But who? Lips, do not move, No man must know._ ‘No man must know.' What follows? The numbers alter'd! ‘No man must know.'-If this should be thee, Malvolio?

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Marry, hang thee, brock!

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: _    I may command where I adore, But silence, like a Lucrece knife, With bloodless stroke my heart doth gore; M.O.A.I. doth sway my life._

dialogues.speaker: Fabian
dialogues.line: A fustian riddle!

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Excellent wench, say I.

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: ‘M.O.A.I. doth sway my life.'-Nay, but first let me see, let me see, let me see.

dialogues.speaker: Fabian
dialogues.line: What dish o' poison has she dressed him!

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: And with what wing the staniel checks at it!

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: ‘I may command where I adore.' Why, she may command me: I serve her, she is my lady. Why, this is evident to any formal capacity. There is no obstruction in this. And the end-what should that alphabetical position portend? If I could make that resemble something in me! Softly! ‘M.O.A.I.'-

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: O, ay, make up that:-he is now at a cold scent.

dialogues.speaker: Fabian
dialogues.line: Sowter will cry upon't for all this, though it be as rank as a fox.

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: ‘M'-Malvolio; ‘M!' Why, that begins my name!

dialogues.speaker: Fabian
dialogues.line: Did not I say he would work it out? The cur is excellent at faults.

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: ‘M'-But then there is no consonancy in the sequel; that suffers under probation: ‘A' should follow, but ‘O' does.

dialogues.speaker: Fabian
dialogues.line: And ‘O' shall end, I hope.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Ay, or I'll cudgel him, and make him cry ‘O!'

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: And then ‘I' comes behind.

dialogues.speaker: Fabian
dialogues.line: Ay, and you had any eye behind you, you might see more detraction at your heels than fortunes before you.

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: ‘M.O.A.I.' This simulation is not as the former: and yet, to crush this a little, it would bow to me, for every one of these letters are in my name. Soft, here follows prose.  _If this fall into thy hand, revolve. In my stars I am above thee, but be not afraid of greatness. Some are born great, some achieve greatness, and some have greatness thrust upon 'em. Thy fates open their hands, let thy blood and spirit embrace them. And, to inure thyself to what thou art like to be, cast thy humble slough and appear fresh. Be opposite with a kinsman, surly with servants. Let thy tongue tang arguments of state; put thyself into the trick of singularity. She thus advises thee that sighs for thee. Remember who commended thy yellow stockings, and wished to see thee ever cross-gartered. I say, remember. Go to, thou art made, if thou desir'st to be so. If not, let me see thee a steward still, the fellow of servants, and not worthy to touch Fortune's fingers. Farewell. She that would alter services with thee, The Fortunate Unhappy._ Daylight and champian discovers not more! This is open. I will be proud, I will read politic authors, I will baffle Sir Toby, I will wash off gross acquaintance, I will be point-device, the very man. I do not now fool myself, to let imagination jade me; for every reason excites to this, that my lady loves me. She did commend my yellow stockings of late, she did praise my leg being cross-gartered, and in this she manifests herself to my love, and with a kind of injunction, drives me to these habits of her liking. I thank my stars, I am happy. I will be strange, stout, in yellow stockings, and cross-gartered, even with the swiftness of putting on. Jove and my stars be praised!-Here is yet a postscript.  _Thou canst not choose but know who I am. If thou entertain'st my love, let it appear in thy smiling; thy smiles become thee well. Therefore in my presence still smile, dear my sweet, I prithee._ Jove, I thank thee. I will smile, I will do everything that thou wilt have me.

dialogues.speaker: Fabian
dialogues.line: I will not give my part of this sport for a pension of thousands to be paid from the Sophy.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: I could marry this wench for this device.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: So could I too.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: And ask no other dowry with her but such another jest.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: Nor I neither.

dialogues.speaker: Fabian
dialogues.line: Here comes my noble gull-catcher.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Wilt thou set thy foot o' my neck?

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: Or o' mine either?

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Shall I play my freedom at tray-trip, and become thy bond-slave?

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: I' faith, or I either?

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Why, thou hast put him in such a dream, that when the image of it leaves him he must run mad.

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: Nay, but say true, does it work upon him?

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Like aqua-vitae with a midwife.

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: If you will then see the fruits of the sport, mark his first approach before my lady: he will come to her in yellow stockings, and 'tis a colour she abhors, and cross-gartered, a fashion she detests; and he will smile upon her, which will now be so unsuitable to her disposition, being addicted to a melancholy as she is, that it cannot but turn him into a notable contempt. If you will see it, follow me.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: To the gates of Tartar, thou most excellent devil of wit!

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: I'll make one too.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: Save thee, friend, and thy music. Dost thou live by thy tabor?

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: No, sir, I live by the church.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: Art thou a churchman?

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: No such matter, sir. I do live by the church, for I do live at my house, and my house doth stand by the church.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: So thou mayst say the king lies by a beggar, if a beggar dwell near him; or the church stands by thy tabor, if thy tabor stand by the church.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: You have said, sir. To see this age! A sentence is but a chev'ril glove to a good wit. How quickly the wrong side may be turned outward!

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: Nay, that's certain; they that dally nicely with words may quickly make them wanton.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: I would, therefore, my sister had had no name, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: Why, man?

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Why, sir, her name's a word; and to dally with that word might make my sister wanton. But indeed, words are very rascals, since bonds disgraced them.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: Thy reason, man?

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Troth, sir, I can yield you none without words, and words are grown so false, I am loath to prove reason with them.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: I warrant thou art a merry fellow, and car'st for nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Not so, sir, I do care for something. But in my conscience, sir, I do not care for you. If that be to care for nothing, sir, I would it would make you invisible.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: Art not thou the Lady Olivia's fool?

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: No, indeed, sir; the Lady Olivia has no folly. She will keep no fool, sir, till she be married, and fools are as like husbands as pilchards are to herrings, the husband's the bigger. I am indeed not her fool, but her corrupter of words.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: I saw thee late at the Count Orsino's.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Foolery, sir, does walk about the orb like the sun; it shines everywhere. I would be sorry, sir, but the fool should be as oft with your master as with my mistress. I think I saw your wisdom there.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: Nay, and thou pass upon me, I'll no more with thee. Hold, there's expenses for thee.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Now Jove, in his next commodity of hair, send thee a beard!

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: By my troth, I'll tell thee, I am almost sick for one, though I would not have it grow on my chin. Is thy lady within?

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Would not a pair of these have bred, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: Yes, being kept together, and put to use.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: I would play Lord Pandarus of Phrygia, sir, to bring a Cressida to this Troilus.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: I understand you, sir; 'tis well begged.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: The matter, I hope, is not great, sir, begging but a beggar: Cressida was a beggar. My lady is within, sir. I will conster to them whence you come; who you are and what you would are out of my welkin. I might say "element", but the word is overworn.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: This fellow is wise enough to play the fool, And to do that well, craves a kind of wit: He must observe their mood on whom he jests, The quality of persons, and the time, And like the haggard, check at every feather That comes before his eye. This is a practice As full of labour as a wise man's art: For folly, that he wisely shows, is fit; But wise men, folly-fall'n, quite taint their wit.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Save you, gentleman.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: And you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: _Dieu vous garde, monsieur._

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: _Et vous aussi; votre serviteur._

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: I hope, sir, you are, and I am yours.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Will you encounter the house? My niece is desirous you should enter, if your trade be to her.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: I am bound to your niece, sir, I mean, she is the list of my voyage.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Taste your legs, sir, put them to motion.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: My legs do better understand me, sir, than I understand what you mean by bidding me taste my legs.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: I mean, to go, sir, to enter.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: I will answer you with gait and entrance: but we are prevented. Most excellent accomplished lady, the heavens rain odours on you!

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: That youth's a rare courtier. ‘Rain odours,' well.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: My matter hath no voice, lady, but to your own most pregnant and vouchsafed ear.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: ‘Odours,' ‘pregnant,' and ‘vouchsafed.'-I'll get 'em all three ready.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Let the garden door be shut, and leave me to my hearing. Give me your hand, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: My duty, madam, and most humble service.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: What is your name?

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: Cesario is your servant's name, fair princess.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: My servant, sir! 'Twas never merry world, Since lowly feigning was call'd compliment: Y'are servant to the Count Orsino, youth.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: And he is yours, and his must needs be yours. Your servant's servant is your servant, madam.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: For him, I think not on him: for his thoughts, Would they were blanks rather than fill'd with me!

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: Madam, I come to whet your gentle thoughts On his behalf.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: O, by your leave, I pray you. I bade you never speak again of him. But would you undertake another suit, I had rather hear you to solicit that Than music from the spheres.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: Dear lady-

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Give me leave, beseech you. I did send, After the last enchantment you did here, A ring in chase of you. So did I abuse Myself, my servant, and, I fear me, you. Under your hard construction must I sit; To force that on you in a shameful cunning, Which you knew none of yours. What might you think? Have you not set mine honour at the stake, And baited it with all th' unmuzzled thoughts That tyrannous heart can think? To one of your receiving Enough is shown. A cypress, not a bosom, Hides my heart: so let me hear you speak.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: I pity you.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: That's a degree to love.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: No, not a grize; for 'tis a vulgar proof That very oft we pity enemies.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Why then methinks 'tis time to smile again. O world, how apt the poor are to be proud! If one should be a prey, how much the better To fall before the lion than the wolf!  The clock upbraids me with the waste of time. Be not afraid, good youth, I will not have you. And yet, when wit and youth is come to harvest, Your wife is like to reap a proper man. There lies your way, due west.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: Then westward ho! Grace and good disposition attend your ladyship! You'll nothing, madam, to my lord by me?

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Stay: I prithee tell me what thou think'st of me.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: That you do think you are not what you are.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: If I think so, I think the same of you.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: Then think you right; I am not what I am.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: I would you were as I would have you be.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: Would it be better, madam, than I am? I wish it might, for now I am your fool.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: O what a deal of scorn looks beautiful In the contempt and anger of his lip! A murd'rous guilt shows not itself more soon Than love that would seem hid. Love's night is noon. Cesario, by the roses of the spring, By maidhood, honour, truth, and everything, I love thee so, that maugre all thy pride, Nor wit nor reason can my passion hide. Do not extort thy reasons from this clause, For that I woo, thou therefore hast no cause; But rather reason thus with reason fetter: Love sought is good, but given unsought is better.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: By innocence I swear, and by my youth, I have one heart, one bosom, and one truth, And that no woman has; nor never none Shall mistress be of it, save I alone. And so adieu, good madam; never more Will I my master's tears to you deplore.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Yet come again: for thou perhaps mayst move That heart, which now abhors, to like his love.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: No, faith, I'll not stay a jot longer.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Thy reason, dear venom, give thy reason.

dialogues.speaker: Fabian
dialogues.line: You must needs yield your reason, Sir Andrew.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: Marry, I saw your niece do more favours to the Count's servingman than ever she bestowed upon me; I saw't i' th' orchard.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Did she see thee the while, old boy? Tell me that.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: As plain as I see you now.

dialogues.speaker: Fabian
dialogues.line: This was a great argument of love in her toward you.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: 'Slight! will you make an ass o' me?

dialogues.speaker: Fabian
dialogues.line: I will prove it legitimate, sir, upon the oaths of judgment and reason.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: And they have been grand-jurymen since before Noah was a sailor.

dialogues.speaker: Fabian
dialogues.line: She did show favour to the youth in your sight only to exasperate you, to awake your dormouse valour, to put fire in your heart and brimstone in your liver. You should then have accosted her, and with some excellent jests, fire-new from the mint, you should have banged the youth into dumbness. This was looked for at your hand, and this was balked: the double gilt of this opportunity you let time wash off, and you are now sailed into the north of my lady's opinion; where you will hang like an icicle on Dutchman's beard, unless you do redeem it by some laudable attempt, either of valour or policy.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: And't be any way, it must be with valour, for policy I hate; I had as lief be a Brownist as a politician.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Why, then, build me thy fortunes upon the basis of valour. Challenge me the Count's youth to fight with him. Hurt him in eleven places; my niece shall take note of it, and assure thyself there is no love-broker in the world can more prevail in man's commendation with woman than report of valour.

dialogues.speaker: Fabian
dialogues.line: There is no way but this, Sir Andrew.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: Will either of you bear me a challenge to him?

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Go, write it in a martial hand, be curst and brief; it is no matter how witty, so it be eloquent and full of invention. Taunt him with the licence of ink. If thou ‘thou'st' him some thrice, it shall not be amiss, and as many lies as will lie in thy sheet of paper, although the sheet were big enough for the bed of Ware in England, set 'em down. Go about it. Let there be gall enough in thy ink, though thou write with a goose-pen, no matter. About it.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: Where shall I find you?

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: We'll call thee at the cubiculo. Go.

dialogues.speaker: Fabian
dialogues.line: This is a dear manikin to you, Sir Toby.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: I have been dear to him, lad, some two thousand strong, or so.

dialogues.speaker: Fabian
dialogues.line: We shall have a rare letter from him; but you'll not deliver it.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
