dialogues.line: Never trust me then. And by all means stir on the youth to an answer. I think oxen and wainropes cannot hale them together. For Andrew, if he were opened and you find so much blood in his liver as will clog the foot of a flea, I'll eat the rest of th' anatomy.

dialogues.speaker: Fabian
dialogues.line: And his opposite, the youth, bears in his visage no great presage of cruelty.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Look where the youngest wren of nine comes.

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: If you desire the spleen, and will laugh yourselves into stitches, follow me. Yond gull Malvolio is turned heathen, a very renegado; for there is no Christian that means to be saved by believing rightly can ever believe such impossible passages of grossness. He's in yellow stockings.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: And cross-gartered?

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: Most villainously; like a pedant that keeps a school i' th' church. I have dogged him like his murderer. He does obey every point of the letter that I dropped to betray him. He does smile his face into more lines than is in the new map with the augmentation of the Indies. You have not seen such a thing as 'tis. I  can hardly forbear hurling things at him. I know my lady will strike him. If she do, he'll smile and take't for a great favour.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Come, bring us, bring us where he is.

dialogues.speaker: Sebastian
dialogues.line: I would not by my will have troubled you, But since you make your pleasure of your pains, I will no further chide you.

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: I could not stay behind you: my desire, More sharp than filed steel, did spur me forth; And not all love to see you, though so much, As might have drawn one to a longer voyage, But jealousy what might befall your travel, Being skilless in these parts; which to a stranger, Unguided and unfriended, often prove Rough and unhospitable. My willing love, The rather by these arguments of fear, Set forth in your pursuit.

dialogues.speaker: Sebastian
dialogues.line: My kind Antonio, I can no other answer make but thanks, And thanks, and ever thanks; and oft good turns Are shuffled off with such uncurrent pay. But were my worth, as is my conscience, firm, You should find better dealing. What's to do? Shall we go see the relics of this town?

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: Tomorrow, sir; best first go see your lodging.

dialogues.speaker: Sebastian
dialogues.line: I am not weary, and 'tis long to night; I pray you, let us satisfy our eyes With the memorials and the things of fame That do renown this city.

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: Would you'd pardon me. I do not without danger walk these streets. Once in a sea-fight, 'gainst the Count his galleys, I did some service, of such note indeed, That were I ta'en here, it would scarce be answer'd.

dialogues.speaker: Sebastian
dialogues.line: Belike you slew great number of his people.

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: Th' offence is not of such a bloody nature, Albeit the quality of the time and quarrel Might well have given us bloody argument. It might have since been answered in repaying What we took from them, which for traffic's sake, Most of our city did. Only myself stood out, For which, if I be lapsed in this place, I shall pay dear.

dialogues.speaker: Sebastian
dialogues.line: Do not then walk too open.

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: It doth not fit me. Hold, sir, here's my purse. In the south suburbs, at the Elephant, Is best to lodge. I will bespeak our diet Whiles you beguile the time and feed your knowledge With viewing of the town. There shall you have me.

dialogues.speaker: Sebastian
dialogues.line: Why I your purse?

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: Haply your eye shall light upon some toy You have desire to purchase; and your store, I think, is not for idle markets, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Sebastian
dialogues.line: I'll be your purse-bearer, and leave you for an hour.

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: To th' Elephant.

dialogues.speaker: Sebastian
dialogues.line: I do remember.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: I have sent after him. He says he'll come; How shall I feast him? What bestow of him? For youth is bought more oft than begg'd or borrow'd. I speak too loud.- Where's Malvolio?-He is sad and civil, And suits well for a servant with my fortunes; Where is Malvolio?

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: He's coming, madam: But in very strange manner. He is sure possessed, madam.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Why, what's the matter? Does he rave?

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: No, madam, he does nothing but smile: your ladyship were best to have some guard about you if he come, for sure the man is tainted in 's wits.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Go call him hither. I'm as mad as he, If sad and merry madness equal be. How now, Malvolio?

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: Sweet lady, ho, ho!

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Smil'st thou? I sent for thee upon a sad occasion.

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: Sad, lady? I could be sad: this does make some obstruction in the blood, this cross-gartering. But what of that? If it please the eye of one, it is with me as the very true sonnet is: ‘Please one and please all.'

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Why, how dost thou, man? What is the matter with thee?

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: Not black in my mind, though yellow in my legs. It did come to his hands, and commands shall be executed. I think we do know the sweet Roman hand.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Wilt thou go to bed, Malvolio?

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: To bed? Ay, sweetheart, and I'll come to thee.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: God comfort thee! Why dost thou smile so, and kiss thy hand so oft?

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: How do you, Malvolio?

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: At your request? Yes, nightingales answer daws!

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: Why appear you with this ridiculous boldness before my lady?

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: ‘Be not afraid of greatness.' 'Twas well writ.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: What mean'st thou by that, Malvolio?

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: ‘Some are born great'-

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Ha?

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: ‘Some achieve greatness'-

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: What say'st thou?

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: ‘And some have greatness thrust upon them.'

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Heaven restore thee!

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: ‘Remember who commended thy yellow stockings'-

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Thy yellow stockings?

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: ‘And wished to see thee cross-gartered.'

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Cross-gartered?

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: ‘Go to: thou art made, if thou desir'st to be so:'-

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Am I made?

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: ‘If not, let me see thee a servant still.'

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Why, this is very midsummer madness.

dialogues.speaker: Servant
dialogues.line: Madam, the young gentleman of the Count Orsino's is returned; I could hardly entreat him back. He attends your ladyship's pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: I'll come to him. Good Maria, let this fellow be looked to. Where's my cousin Toby? Let some of my people have a special care of him; I would not have him miscarry for the half of my dowry.

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: O ho, do you come near me now? No worse man than Sir Toby to look to me. This concurs directly with the letter: she sends him on purpose, that I may appear stubborn to him; for she incites me to that in the letter. ‘Cast thy humble slough,' says she; ‘be opposite with a kinsman, surly with servants, let thy tongue tang with arguments of state, put thyself into the trick of singularity,' and consequently, sets down the manner how: as, a sad face, a reverend carriage, a slow tongue, in the habit of some sir of note, and so forth. I have limed her, but it is Jove's doing, and Jove make me thankful! And when she went away now, ‘Let this fellow be looked to;' ‘Fellow!' not ‘Malvolio', nor after my degree, but ‘fellow'. Why, everything adheres together, that no dram of a scruple, no scruple of a scruple, no obstacle, no incredulous or unsafe circumstance. What can be said? Nothing that can be can come between me and the full prospect of my hopes. Well, Jove, not I, is the doer of this, and he is to be thanked.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Which way is he, in the name of sanctity? If all the devils of hell be drawn in little, and Legion himself possessed him, yet I'll speak to him.

dialogues.speaker: Fabian
dialogues.line: Here he is, here he is. How is't with you, sir? How is't with you, man?

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: Go off, I discard you. Let me enjoy my private. Go off.

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: Lo, how hollow the fiend speaks within him! Did not I tell you? Sir Toby, my lady prays you to have a care of him.

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: Ah, ha! does she so?

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Go to, go to; peace, peace, we must deal gently with him. Let me alone. How do you, Malvolio? How is't with you? What, man! defy the devil! Consider, he's an enemy to mankind.

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: Do you know what you say?

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: La you, an you speak ill of the devil, how he takes it at heart! Pray God he be not bewitched.

dialogues.speaker: Fabian
dialogues.line: Carry his water to th' wise woman.

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: Marry, and it shall be done tomorrow morning, if I live. My lady would not lose him for more than I'll say.

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: How now, mistress!

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: O Lord!

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Prithee hold thy peace, this is not the way. Do you not see you move him? Let me alone with him.

dialogues.speaker: Fabian
dialogues.line: No way but gentleness, gently, gently. The fiend is rough, and will not be roughly used.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Why, how now, my bawcock? How dost thou, chuck?

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: Sir!

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Ay, biddy, come with me. What, man, 'tis not for gravity to play at cherry-pit with Satan. Hang him, foul collier!

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: Get him to say his prayers, good Sir Toby, get him to pray.

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: My prayers, minx?

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: No, I warrant you, he will not hear of godliness.

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: Go, hang yourselves all! You are idle, shallow things. I am not of your element. You shall know more hereafter.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Is't possible?

dialogues.speaker: Fabian
dialogues.line: If this were played upon a stage now, I could condemn it as an improbable fiction.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: His very genius hath taken the infection of the device, man.

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: Nay, pursue him now, lest the device take air and taint.

dialogues.speaker: Fabian
dialogues.line: Why, we shall make him mad indeed.

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: The house will be the quieter.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Come, we'll have him in a dark room and bound. My niece is already in the belief that he's mad. We may carry it thus for our pleasure, and his penance, till our very pastime, tired out of breath, prompt us to have mercy on him, at which time we will bring the device to the bar, and crown thee for a finder of madmen. But see, but see!

dialogues.speaker: Fabian
dialogues.line: More matter for a May morning.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: Here's the challenge, read it. I warrant there's vinegar and pepper in't.

dialogues.speaker: Fabian
dialogues.line: Is't so saucy?

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: Ay, is't, I warrant him. Do but read.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Give me.  _Youth, whatsoever thou art, thou art but a scurvy fellow._

dialogues.speaker: Fabian
dialogues.line: Good, and valiant.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: _Wonder not, nor admire not in thy mind, why I do call thee so, for I will show thee no reason for't._

dialogues.speaker: Fabian
dialogues.line: A good note, that keeps you from the blow of the law.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: _Thou comest to the Lady Olivia, and in my sight she uses thee kindly: but thou liest in thy throat; that is not the matter I challenge thee for._

dialogues.speaker: Fabian
dialogues.line: Very brief, and to exceeding good sense-less.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: _I will waylay thee going home; where if it be thy chance to kill me-_

dialogues.speaker: Fabian
dialogues.line: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: _Thou kill'st me like a rogue and a villain._

dialogues.speaker: Fabian
dialogues.line: Still you keep o' th' windy side of the law. Good.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: _Fare thee well, and God have mercy upon one of our souls! He may have mercy upon mine, but my hope is better, and so look to thyself. Thy friend, as thou usest him, and thy sworn enemy, Andrew Aguecheek._ If this letter move him not, his legs cannot. I'll give't him.

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: You may have very fit occasion for't. He is now in some commerce with my lady, and will by and by depart.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Go, Sir Andrew. Scout me for him at the corner of the orchard, like a bum-baily. So soon as ever thou seest him, draw, and as thou draw'st, swear horrible, for it comes to pass oft that a terrible oath, with a swaggering accent sharply twanged off, gives manhood more approbation than ever proof itself would have earned him. Away.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: Nay, let me alone for swearing.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Now will not I deliver his letter, for the behaviour of the young gentleman gives him out to be of good capacity and breeding; his employment between his lord and my niece confirms no less. Therefore this letter, being so excellently ignorant, will breed no terror in the youth. He will find it comes from a clodpole. But, sir, I will deliver his challenge by word of mouth, set upon Aguecheek notable report of valour, and drive the gentleman (as I know his youth will aptly receive it) into a most hideous opinion of his rage, skill, fury, and impetuosity. This will so fright them both that they will kill one another by the look, like cockatrices.

dialogues.speaker: Fabian
dialogues.line: Here he comes with your niece; give them way till he take leave, and presently after him.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: I will meditate the while upon some horrid message for a challenge.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: I have said too much unto a heart of stone, And laid mine honour too unchary on't: There's something in me that reproves my fault: But such a headstrong potent fault it is, That it but mocks reproof.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: With the same 'haviour that your passion bears Goes on my master's griefs.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Here, wear this jewel for me, 'tis my picture. Refuse it not, it hath no tongue to vex you. And I beseech you come again tomorrow. What shall you ask of me that I'll deny, That honour sav'd, may upon asking give?

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: Nothing but this, your true love for my master.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: How with mine honour may I give him that Which I have given to you?

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: I will acquit you.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Well, come again tomorrow. Fare thee well; A fiend like thee might bear my soul to hell.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Gentleman, God save thee.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: And you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: That defence thou hast, betake thee to't. Of what nature the wrongs are thou hast done him, I know not, but thy intercepter, full of despite, bloody as the hunter, attends thee at the orchard end. Dismount thy tuck, be yare in thy preparation, for thy assailant is quick, skilful, and deadly.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: You mistake, sir; I am sure no man hath any quarrel to me. My remembrance is very free and clear from any image of offence done to any man.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: You'll find it otherwise, I assure you. Therefore, if you hold your life at any price, betake you to your guard, for your opposite hath in him what youth, strength, skill, and wrath, can furnish man withal.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: I pray you, sir, what is he?

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: He is knight, dubbed with unhatched rapier, and on carpet consideration, but he is a devil in private brawl. Souls and bodies hath he divorced three, and his incensement at this moment is so implacable that satisfaction can be none but by pangs of death and sepulchre. Hob, nob is his word; give't or take't.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: I will return again into the house and desire some conduct of the lady. I am no fighter. I have heard of some kind of men that put quarrels purposely on others to taste their valour: belike this is a man of that quirk.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Sir, no. His indignation derives itself out of a very competent injury; therefore, get you on and give him his desire. Back you shall not to the house, unless you undertake that with me which with as much safety you might answer him. Therefore on, or strip your sword stark naked, for meddle you must, that's certain, or forswear to wear iron about you.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: This is as uncivil as strange. I beseech you, do me this courteous office, as to know of the knight what my offence to him is. It is something of my negligence, nothing of my purpose.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: I will do so. Signior Fabian, stay you by this gentleman till my return.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: Pray you, sir, do you know of this matter?

dialogues.speaker: Fabian
dialogues.line: I know the knight is incensed against you, even to a mortal arbitrement, but nothing of the circumstance more.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: I beseech you, what manner of man is he?

dialogues.speaker: Fabian
dialogues.line: Nothing of that wonderful promise, to read him by his form, as you are like to find him in the proof of his valour. He is indeed, sir, the most skilful, bloody, and fatal opposite that you could possibly have found in any part of Illyria. Will you walk towards him? I will make your peace with him if I can.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: I shall be much bound to you for't. I am one that had rather go with sir priest than sir knight: I care not who knows so much of my mettle.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Why, man, he's a very devil. I have not seen such a firago. I had a pass with him, rapier, scabbard, and all, and he gives me the stuck-in with such a mortal motion that it is inevitable; and on the answer, he pays you as surely as your feet hits the ground they step on. They say he has been fencer to the Sophy.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: Pox on't, I'll not meddle with him.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Ay, but he will not now be pacified: Fabian can scarce hold him yonder.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: Plague on't, an I thought he had been valiant, and so cunning in fence, I'd have seen him damned ere I'd have challenged him. Let him let the matter slip, and I'll give him my horse, grey Capilet.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: I'll make the motion. Stand here, make a good show on't. This shall end without the perdition of souls.  Marry, I'll ride your horse as well as I ride you.  I have his horse to take up the quarrel. I have persuaded him the youth's a devil.

dialogues.speaker: Fabian
dialogues.line: He is as horribly conceited of him, and pants and looks pale, as if a bear were at his heels.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: There's no remedy, sir, he will fight with you for's oath sake. Marry, he hath better bethought him of his quarrel, and he finds that now scarce to be worth talking of. Therefore, draw for the supportance of his vow; he protests he will not hurt you.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: Pray God defend me! A little thing would make me tell them how much I lack of a man.

dialogues.speaker: Fabian
dialogues.line: Give ground if you see him furious.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Come, Sir Andrew, there's no remedy, the gentleman will for his honour's sake have one bout with you. He cannot by the duello avoid it; but he has promised me, as he is a gentleman and a soldier, he will not hurt you. Come on: to't.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: Pray God he keep his oath!

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: I do assure you 'tis against my will.

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: Put up your sword. If this young gentleman Have done offence, I take the fault on me. If you offend him, I for him defy you.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: You, sir? Why, what are you?

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: One, sir, that for his love dares yet do more Than you have heard him brag to you he will.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Nay, if you be an undertaker, I am for you.

dialogues.speaker: Fabian
dialogues.line: O good Sir Toby, hold! Here come the officers.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: I'll be with you anon.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: Pray, sir, put your sword up, if you please.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: Marry, will I, sir; and for that I promised you, I'll be as good as my word. He will bear you easily, and reins well.

dialogues.speaker: First Officer
dialogues.line: This is the man; do thy office.

dialogues.speaker: Second Officer
dialogues.line: Antonio, I arrest thee at the suit Of Count Orsino.

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: You do mistake me, sir.

dialogues.speaker: First Officer
dialogues.line: No, sir, no jot. I know your favour well, Though now you have no sea-cap on your head.- Take him away, he knows I know him well.

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: I must obey. This comes with seeking you; But there's no remedy, I shall answer it. What will you do? Now my necessity Makes me to ask you for my purse. It grieves me Much more for what I cannot do for you, Than what befalls myself. You stand amaz'd, But be of comfort.

dialogues.speaker: Second Officer
dialogues.line: Come, sir, away.

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: I must entreat of you some of that money.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: What money, sir? For the fair kindness you have show'd me here, And part being prompted by your present trouble, Out of my lean and low ability I'll lend you something. My having is not much; I'll make division of my present with you. Hold, there's half my coffer.

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: Will you deny me now? Is't possible that my deserts to you Can lack persuasion? Do not tempt my misery, Lest that it make me so unsound a man As to upbraid you with those kindnesses That I have done for you.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: I know of none, Nor know I you by voice or any feature. I hate ingratitude more in a man Than lying, vainness, babbling, drunkenness, Or any taint of vice whose strong corruption Inhabits our frail blood.

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: O heavens themselves!

dialogues.speaker: Second Officer
dialogues.line: Come, sir, I pray you go.

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: Let me speak a little. This youth that you see here I snatch'd one half out of the jaws of death, Reliev'd him with such sanctity of love; And to his image, which methought did promise Most venerable worth, did I devotion.

dialogues.speaker: First Officer
dialogues.line: What's that to us? The time goes by. Away!

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: But O how vile an idol proves this god! Thou hast, Sebastian, done good feature shame. In nature there's no blemish but the mind; None can be call'd deform'd but the unkind. Virtue is beauty, but the beauteous evil Are empty trunks, o'erflourished by the devil.

dialogues.speaker: First Officer
dialogues.line: The man grows mad, away with him. Come, come, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: Lead me on.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: Methinks his words do from such passion fly That he believes himself; so do not I. Prove true, imagination, O prove true, That I, dear brother, be now ta'en for you!

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Come hither, knight; come hither, Fabian. We'll whisper o'er a couplet or two of most sage saws.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: He nam'd Sebastian. I my brother know Yet living in my glass; even such and so In favour was my brother, and he went Still in this fashion, colour, ornament, For him I imitate. O if it prove, Tempests are kind, and salt waves fresh in love!

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: A very dishonest paltry boy, and more a coward than a hare. His dishonesty appears in leaving his friend here in necessity, and denying him; and for his cowardship, ask Fabian.

dialogues.speaker: Fabian
dialogues.line: A coward, a most devout coward, religious in it.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: 'Slid, I'll after him again and beat him.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Do, cuff him soundly, but never draw thy sword.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: And I do not-

dialogues.speaker: Fabian
dialogues.line: Come, let's see the event.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: I dare lay any money 'twill be nothing yet.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Will you make me believe that I am not sent for you?

dialogues.speaker: Sebastian
dialogues.line: Go to, go to, thou art a foolish fellow. Let me be clear of thee.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Well held out, i' faith! No, I do not know you, nor I am not sent to you by my lady, to bid you come speak with her; nor your name is not Master Cesario; nor this is not my nose neither. Nothing that is so, is so.

dialogues.speaker: Sebastian
dialogues.line: I prithee vent thy folly somewhere else, Thou know'st not me.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Vent my folly! He has heard that word of some great man, and now applies it to a fool. Vent my folly! I am afraid this great lubber, the world, will prove a cockney. I prithee now, ungird thy strangeness, and tell me what I shall vent to my lady. Shall I vent to her that thou art coming?

dialogues.speaker: Sebastian
dialogues.line: I prithee, foolish Greek, depart from me. There's money for thee; if you tarry longer I shall give worse payment.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: By my troth, thou hast an open hand. These wise men that give fools money get themselves a good report-after fourteen years' purchase.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: Now sir, have I met you again? There's for you.

dialogues.speaker: Sebastian
dialogues.line: Why, there's for thee, and there, and there. Are all the people mad?

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Hold, sir, or I'll throw your dagger o'er the house.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: This will I tell my lady straight. I would not be in some of your coats for twopence.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Come on, sir, hold!

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: Nay, let him alone, I'll go another way to work with him. I'll have an action of battery against him, if there be any law in Illyria. Though I struck him first, yet it's no matter for that.

dialogues.speaker: Sebastian
dialogues.line: Let go thy hand!

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Come, sir, I will not let you go. Come, my young soldier, put up your iron: you are well fleshed. Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Sebastian
dialogues.line: I will be free from thee. What wouldst thou now? If thou dar'st tempt me further, draw thy sword.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: What, what? Nay, then, I must have an ounce or two of this malapert blood from you.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Hold, Toby! On thy life I charge thee hold!

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Madam.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Will it be ever thus? Ungracious wretch, Fit for the mountains and the barbarous caves, Where manners ne'er were preach'd! Out of my sight! Be not offended, dear Cesario. Rudesby, be gone! I prithee, gentle friend, Let thy fair wisdom, not thy passion, sway In this uncivil and unjust extent Against thy peace. Go with me to my house, And hear thou there how many fruitless pranks This ruffian hath botch'd up, that thou thereby Mayst smile at this. Thou shalt not choose but go. Do not deny. Beshrew his soul for me, He started one poor heart of mine, in thee.

dialogues.speaker: Sebastian
dialogues.line: What relish is in this? How runs the stream? Or I am mad, or else this is a dream. Let fancy still my sense in Lethe steep; If it be thus to dream, still let me sleep!

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Nay, come, I prithee. Would thou'dst be ruled by me!

dialogues.speaker: Sebastian
dialogues.line: Madam, I will.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: O, say so, and so be!

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: Nay, I prithee, put on this gown and this beard; make him believe thou art Sir Topas the curate. Do it quickly. I'll call Sir Toby the whilst.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Well, I'll put it on, and I will dissemble myself in't, and I would I were the first that ever dissembled in such a gown. I am not tall enough to become the function well, nor lean enough to be thought a good student, but to be said, an honest man and a good housekeeper goes as fairly as to say, a careful man and a great scholar. The competitors

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Jove bless thee, Master Parson.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: _Bonos dies_, Sir Toby: for as the old hermit of Prague, that never saw pen and ink, very wittily said to a niece of King Gorboduc, ‘That that is, is': so I, being Master Parson, am Master Parson; for what is ‘that' but ‘that'? and ‘is' but ‘is'?

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: To him, Sir Topas.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: What ho, I say! Peace in this prison!

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: The knave counterfeits well. A good knave. Malvolio within.

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: Who calls there?

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Sir Topas the curate, who comes to visit Malvolio the lunatic.

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: Sir Topas, Sir Topas, good Sir Topas, go to my lady.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Out, hyperbolical fiend! how vexest thou this man? Talkest thou nothing but of ladies?

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Well said, Master Parson.

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: Sir Topas, never was man thus wronged. Good Sir Topas, do not think I am mad. They have laid me here in hideous darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Fie, thou dishonest Satan! I call thee by the most modest terms, for I am one of those gentle ones that will use the devil himself with courtesy. Say'st thou that house is dark?

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: As hell, Sir Topas.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Why, it hath bay windows transparent as barricadoes, and the clerestories toward the south-north are as lustrous as ebony; and yet complainest thou of obstruction?

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: I am not mad, Sir Topas. I say to you this house is dark.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Madman, thou errest. I say there is no darkness but ignorance, in which thou art more puzzled than the Egyptians in their fog.

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: I say this house is as dark as ignorance, though ignorance were as dark as hell; and I say there was never man thus abused. I am no more mad than you are. Make the trial of it in any constant question.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: What is the opinion of Pythagoras concerning wildfowl?

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: That the soul of our grandam might haply inhabit a bird.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: What think'st thou of his opinion?

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: I think nobly of the soul, and no way approve his opinion.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Fare thee well. Remain thou still in darkness. Thou shalt hold the opinion of Pythagoras ere I will allow of thy wits, and fear to kill a woodcock, lest thou dispossess the soul of thy grandam. Fare thee well.

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: Sir Topas, Sir Topas!

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: My most exquisite Sir Topas!

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Nay, I am for all waters.

dialogues.speaker: Maria
dialogues.line: Thou mightst have done this without thy beard and gown. He sees thee not.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: To him in thine own voice, and bring me word how thou find'st him. I would we were well rid of this knavery. If he may be conveniently delivered, I would he were, for I am now so far in offence with my niece that I cannot pursue with any safety this sport to the upshot. Come by and by to my chamber.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: _Hey, Robin, jolly Robin, Tell me how thy lady does._

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: Fool!

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: _My lady is unkind, perdy._

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: Fool!

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: _Alas, why is she so?_

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: Fool, I say!

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: _She loves another_- Who calls, ha?

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: Good fool, as ever thou wilt deserve well at my hand, help me to a candle, and pen, ink, and paper. As I am a gentleman, I will live to be thankful to thee for't.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Master Malvolio?

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: Ay, good fool.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Alas, sir, how fell you besides your five wits?

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: Fool, there was never man so notoriously abused. I am as well in my wits, fool, as thou art.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: But as well? Then you are mad indeed, if you be no better in your wits than a fool.

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: They have here propertied me; keep me in darkness, send ministers to me, asses, and do all they can to face me out of my wits.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Advise you what you say: the minister is here.  Malvolio, Malvolio, thy wits the heavens restore. Endeavour thyself to sleep, and leave thy vain bibble-babble.

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: Sir Topas!

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Maintain no words with him, good fellow.  Who, I, sir? not I, sir. God buy you, good Sir Topas.  Marry, amen.  I will sir, I will.

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: Fool, fool, fool, I say!

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Alas, sir, be patient. What say you, sir? I am shent for speaking to you.

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: Good fool, help me to some light and some paper. I tell thee I am as well in my wits as any man in Illyria.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Well-a-day that you were, sir!

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: By this hand, I am. Good fool, some ink, paper, and light, and convey what I will set down to my lady. It shall advantage thee more than ever the bearing of letter did.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: I will help you to't. But tell me true, are you not mad indeed? or do you but counterfeit?

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: Believe me, I am not. I tell thee true.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Nay, I'll ne'er believe a madman till I see his brains. I will fetch you light, and paper, and ink.

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: Fool, I'll requite it in the highest degree: I prithee be gone.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: _I am gone, sir, and anon, sir, I'll be with you again, In a trice, like to the old Vice, Your need to sustain; Who with dagger of lath, in his rage and his wrath, Cries ‘ah, ha!' to the devil: Like a mad lad, ‘Pare thy nails, dad. Adieu, goodman devil.'_

dialogues.speaker: Sebastian
dialogues.line: This is the air; that is the glorious sun, This pearl she gave me, I do feel't and see't, And though 'tis wonder that enwraps me thus, Yet 'tis not madness. Where's Antonio, then? I could not find him at the Elephant, Yet there he was, and there I found this credit, That he did range the town to seek me out. His counsel now might do me golden service. For though my soul disputes well with my sense That this may be some error, but no madness, Yet doth this accident and flood of fortune So far exceed all instance, all discourse, That I am ready to distrust mine eyes And wrangle with my reason that persuades me To any other trust but that I am mad, Or else the lady's mad; yet if 'twere so, She could not sway her house, command her followers, Take and give back affairs and their dispatch, With such a smooth, discreet, and stable bearing As I perceive she does. There's something in't That is deceivable. But here the lady comes.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Blame not this haste of mine. If you mean well, Now go with me and with this holy man Into the chantry by: there, before him And underneath that consecrated roof, Plight me the full assurance of your faith, That my most jealous and too doubtful soul May live at peace. He shall conceal it Whiles you are willing it shall come to note, What time we will our celebration keep According to my birth. What do you say?

dialogues.speaker: Sebastian
dialogues.line: I'll follow this good man, and go with you, And having sworn truth, ever will be true.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Then lead the way, good father, and heavens so shine, That they may fairly note this act of mine!

dialogues.speaker: Fabian
dialogues.line: Now, as thou lov'st me, let me see his letter.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Good Master Fabian, grant me another request.

dialogues.speaker: Fabian
dialogues.line: Anything.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Do not desire to see this letter.

dialogues.speaker: Fabian
dialogues.line: This is to give a dog, and in recompense desire my dog again.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Belong you to the Lady Olivia, friends?

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Ay, sir, we are some of her trappings.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: I know thee well. How dost thou, my good fellow?

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Truly, sir, the better for my foes, and the worse for my friends.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Just the contrary; the better for thy friends.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: No, sir, the worse.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: How can that be?

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Marry, sir, they praise me, and make an ass of me. Now my foes tell me plainly I am an ass: so that by my foes, sir, I profit in the knowledge of myself, and by my friends I am abused. So that, conclusions to be as kisses, if your four negatives make your two affirmatives, why then, the worse for my friends, and the better for my foes.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Why, this is excellent.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: By my troth, sir, no; though it please you to be one of my friends.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Thou shalt not be the worse for me; there's gold.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: But that it would be double-dealing, sir, I would you could make it another.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: O, you give me ill counsel.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Put your grace in your pocket, sir, for this once, and let your flesh and blood obey it.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Well, I will be so much a sinner to be a double-dealer: there's another.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: _Primo, secundo, tertio_, is a good play, and the old saying is, the third pays for all; the triplex, sir, is a good tripping measure; or the bells of Saint Bennet, sir, may put you in mind-one, two, three.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: You can fool no more money out of me at this throw. If you will let your lady know I am here to speak with her, and bring her along with you, it may awake my bounty further.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Marry, sir, lullaby to your bounty till I come again. I go, sir, but I would not have you to think that my desire of having is the sin of covetousness: but as you say, sir, let your bounty take a nap, I will awake it anon.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: Here comes the man, sir, that did rescue me.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: That face of his I do remember well. Yet when I saw it last it was besmear'd As black as Vulcan, in the smoke of war. A baubling vessel was he captain of, For shallow draught and bulk unprizable, With which such scathful grapple did he make With the most noble bottom of our fleet, That very envy and the tongue of loss Cried fame and honour on him. What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: First Officer
dialogues.line: Orsino, this is that Antonio That took the _Phoenix_ and her fraught from Candy, And this is he that did the _Tiger_ board When your young nephew Titus lost his leg. Here in the streets, desperate of shame and state, In private brabble did we apprehend him.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: He did me kindness, sir; drew on my side, But in conclusion, put strange speech upon me. I know not what 'twas, but distraction.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Notable pirate, thou salt-water thief, What foolish boldness brought thee to their mercies, Whom thou, in terms so bloody and so dear, Hast made thine enemies?

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: Orsino, noble sir, Be pleased that I shake off these names you give me: Antonio never yet was thief or pirate, Though, I confess, on base and ground enough, Orsino's enemy. A witchcraft drew me hither: That most ingrateful boy there by your side From the rude sea's enraged and foamy mouth Did I redeem; a wreck past hope he was. His life I gave him, and did thereto add My love, without retention or restraint, All his in dedication. For his sake Did I expose myself, pure for his love, Into the danger of this adverse town; Drew to defend him when he was beset; Where being apprehended, his false cunning (Not meaning to partake with me in danger) Taught him to face me out of his acquaintance, And grew a twenty years' removed thing While one would wink; denied me mine own purse, Which I had recommended to his use Not half an hour before.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: How can this be?

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: When came he to this town?

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: Today, my lord; and for three months before, No int'rim, not a minute's vacancy, Both day and night did we keep company.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Here comes the Countess, now heaven walks on earth. But for thee, fellow, fellow, thy words are madness. Three months this youth hath tended upon me; But more of that anon. Take him aside.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: What would my lord, but that he may not have, Wherein Olivia may seem serviceable? Cesario, you do not keep promise with me.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: Madam?

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Gracious Olivia-

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: What do you say, Cesario? Good my lord-

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: My lord would speak, my duty hushes me.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: If it be aught to the old tune, my lord, It is as fat and fulsome to mine ear As howling after music.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Still so cruel?

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Still so constant, lord.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: What, to perverseness? You uncivil lady, To whose ingrate and unauspicious altars My soul the faithfull'st off'rings hath breathed out That e'er devotion tender'd! What shall I do?

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Even what it please my lord that shall become him.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Why should I not, had I the heart to do it, Like to the Egyptian thief at point of death, Kill what I love?-a savage jealousy That sometime savours nobly. But hear me this: Since you to non-regardance cast my faith, And that I partly know the instrument That screws me from my true place in your favour, Live you the marble-breasted tyrant still. But this your minion, whom I know you love, And whom, by heaven I swear, I tender dearly, Him will I tear out of that cruel eye Where he sits crowned in his master's spite.- Come, boy, with me; my thoughts are ripe in mischief: I'll sacrifice the lamb that I do love, To spite a raven's heart within a dove.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: And I, most jocund, apt, and willingly, To do you rest, a thousand deaths would die.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Where goes Cesario?

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: After him I love More than I love these eyes, more than my life, More, by all mores, than e'er I shall love wife. If I do feign, you witnesses above Punish my life for tainting of my love.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Ah me, detested! how am I beguil'd!

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: Who does beguile you? Who does do you wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Hast thou forgot thyself? Is it so long? Call forth the holy father.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Come, away!

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Whither, my lord? Cesario, husband, stay.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Husband?

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Ay, husband. Can he that deny?

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Her husband, sirrah?

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: No, my lord, not I.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Alas, it is the baseness of thy fear That makes thee strangle thy propriety. Fear not, Cesario, take thy fortunes up. Be that thou know'st thou art, and then thou art As great as that thou fear'st. O, welcome, father! Father, I charge thee, by thy reverence Here to unfold-though lately we intended To keep in darkness what occasion now Reveals before 'tis ripe-what thou dost know Hath newly passed between this youth and me.

dialogues.speaker: Priest
dialogues.line: A contract of eternal bond of love, Confirmed by mutual joinder of your hands, Attested by the holy close of lips, Strengthen'd by interchangement of your rings, And all the ceremony of this compact Sealed in my function, by my testimony; Since when, my watch hath told me, toward my grave, I have travelled but two hours.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: O thou dissembling cub! What wilt thou be When time hath sowed a grizzle on thy case? Or will not else thy craft so quickly grow That thine own trip shall be thine overthrow? Farewell, and take her; but direct thy feet Where thou and I henceforth may never meet.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: My lord, I do protest-

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: O, do not swear. Hold little faith, though thou has too much fear.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: For the love of God, a surgeon! Send one presently to Sir Toby.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: 'Has broke my head across, and has given Sir Toby a bloody coxcomb too. For the love of God, your help! I had rather than forty pound I were at home.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Who has done this, Sir Andrew?

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: The Count's gentleman, one Cesario. We took him for a coward, but he's the very devil incardinate.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: My gentleman, Cesario?

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: 'Od's lifelings, here he is!-You broke my head for nothing; and that that I did, I was set on to do't by Sir Toby.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: Why do you speak to me? I never hurt you: You drew your sword upon me without cause, But I bespake you fair and hurt you not.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: If a bloody coxcomb be a hurt, you have hurt me. I think you set nothing by a bloody coxcomb. Here comes Sir Toby halting, you shall hear more: but if he had not been in drink, he would have tickled you othergates than he did.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: How now, gentleman? How is't with you?

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: That's all one; 'has hurt me, and there's th' end on't. Sot, didst see Dick Surgeon, sot?

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: O, he's drunk, Sir Toby, an hour agone; his eyes were set at eight i' th' morning.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Then he's a rogue, and a passy measures pavin. I hate a drunken rogue.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Away with him. Who hath made this havoc with them?

dialogues.speaker: Sir Andrew
dialogues.line: I'll help you, Sir Toby, because we'll be dressed together.

dialogues.speaker: Sir Toby
dialogues.line: Will you help? An ass-head, and a coxcomb, and a knave, a thin-faced knave, a gull?

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Get him to bed, and let his hurt be looked to.

dialogues.speaker: Sebastian
dialogues.line: I am sorry, madam, I have hurt your kinsman; But had it been the brother of my blood, I must have done no less with wit and safety. You throw a strange regard upon me, and by that I do perceive it hath offended you. Pardon me, sweet one, even for the vows We made each other but so late ago.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: One face, one voice, one habit, and two persons! A natural perspective, that is, and is not!

dialogues.speaker: Sebastian
dialogues.line: Antonio, O my dear Antonio! How have the hours rack'd and tortur'd me Since I have lost thee.

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: Sebastian are you?

dialogues.speaker: Sebastian
dialogues.line: Fear'st thou that, Antonio?

dialogues.speaker: Antonio
dialogues.line: How have you made division of yourself? An apple cleft in two is not more twin Than these two creatures. Which is Sebastian?

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Most wonderful!

dialogues.speaker: Sebastian
dialogues.line: Do I stand there? I never had a brother: Nor can there be that deity in my nature Of here and everywhere. I had a sister, Whom the blind waves and surges have devoured. Of charity, what kin are you to me? What countryman? What name? What parentage?

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: Of Messaline: Sebastian was my father; Such a Sebastian was my brother too: So went he suited to his watery tomb. If spirits can assume both form and suit, You come to fright us.

dialogues.speaker: Sebastian
dialogues.line: A spirit I am indeed, But am in that dimension grossly clad, Which from the womb I did participate. Were you a woman, as the rest goes even, I should my tears let fall upon your cheek, And say, ‘Thrice welcome, drowned Viola.'

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: My father had a mole upon his brow.

dialogues.speaker: Sebastian
dialogues.line: And so had mine.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: And died that day when Viola from her birth Had numbered thirteen years.

dialogues.speaker: Sebastian
dialogues.line: O, that record is lively in my soul! He finished indeed his mortal act That day that made my sister thirteen years.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: If nothing lets to make us happy both But this my masculine usurp'd attire, Do not embrace me till each circumstance Of place, time, fortune, do cohere and jump That I am Viola; which to confirm, I'll bring you to a captain in this town, Where lie my maiden weeds; by whose gentle help I was preserv'd to serve this noble count. All the occurrence of my fortune since Hath been between this lady and this lord.

dialogues.speaker: Sebastian
dialogues.line: So comes it, lady, you have been mistook. But nature to her bias drew in that. You would have been contracted to a maid; Nor are you therein, by my life, deceived: You are betroth'd both to a maid and man.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Be not amazed; right noble is his blood. If this be so, as yet the glass seems true, I shall have share in this most happy wreck.  Boy, thou hast said to me a thousand times Thou never shouldst love woman like to me.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: And all those sayings will I over-swear, And all those swearings keep as true in soul As doth that orbed continent the fire That severs day from night.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Give me thy hand, And let me see thee in thy woman's weeds.

dialogues.speaker: Viola
dialogues.line: The captain that did bring me first on shore Hath my maid's garments. He, upon some action, Is now in durance, at Malvolio's suit, A gentleman and follower of my lady's.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: He shall enlarge him. Fetch Malvolio hither. And yet, alas, now I remember me, They say, poor gentleman, he's much distract. A most extracting frenzy of mine own From my remembrance clearly banished his. How does he, sirrah?

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Truly, madam, he holds Belzebub at the stave's end as well as a man in his case may do. Has here writ a letter to you. I should have given it you today morning, but as a madman's epistles are no gospels, so it skills not much when they are delivered.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Open 't, and read it.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Look then to be well edified, when the fool delivers the madman. _By the Lord, madam,-_

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: How now, art thou mad?

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: No, madam, I do but read madness: an your ladyship will have it as it ought to be, you must allow _vox_.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Prithee, read i' thy right wits.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: So I do, madonna. But to read his right wits is to read thus; therefore perpend, my princess, and give ear.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Read it you, sirrah.

dialogues.speaker: Fabian
dialogues.line: _By the Lord, madam, you wrong me, and the world shall know it. Though you have put me into darkness and given your drunken cousin rule over me, yet have I the benefit of my senses as well as your ladyship. I have your own letter that induced me to the semblance I put on; with the which I doubt not but to do myself much right or you much shame. Think of me as you please. I leave my duty a little unthought of, and speak out of my injury. The madly-used Malvolio._

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Did he write this?

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Ay, madam.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: This savours not much of distraction.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: See him delivered, Fabian, bring him hither. My lord, so please you, these things further thought on, To think me as well a sister, as a wife, One day shall crown th' alliance on't, so please you, Here at my house, and at my proper cost.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Madam, I am most apt t' embrace your offer.  Your master quits you; and for your service done him, So much against the mettle of your sex, So far beneath your soft and tender breeding, And since you call'd me master for so long, Here is my hand; you shall from this time be Your master's mistress.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: A sister? You are she.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Is this the madman?

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Ay, my lord, this same. How now, Malvolio?

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: Madam, you have done me wrong, Notorious wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Have I, Malvolio? No.

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: Lady, you have. Pray you peruse that letter. You must not now deny it is your hand, Write from it, if you can, in hand, or phrase, Or say 'tis not your seal, not your invention: You can say none of this. Well, grant it then, And tell me, in the modesty of honour, Why you have given me such clear lights of favour, Bade me come smiling and cross-garter'd to you, To put on yellow stockings, and to frown Upon Sir Toby, and the lighter people; And acting this in an obedient hope, Why have you suffer'd me to be imprison'd, Kept in a dark house, visited by the priest, And made the most notorious geck and gull That e'er invention played on? Tell me why?

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Alas, Malvolio, this is not my writing, Though I confess, much like the character: But out of question, 'tis Maria's hand. And now I do bethink me, it was she First told me thou wast mad; then cam'st in smiling, And in such forms which here were presuppos'd Upon thee in the letter. Prithee, be content. This practice hath most shrewdly pass'd upon thee. But when we know the grounds and authors of it, Thou shalt be both the plaintiff and the judge Of thine own cause.

dialogues.speaker: Fabian
dialogues.line: Good madam, hear me speak, And let no quarrel, nor no brawl to come, Taint the condition of this present hour, Which I have wonder'd at. In hope it shall not, Most freely I confess, myself and Toby Set this device against Malvolio here, Upon some stubborn and uncourteous parts We had conceiv'd against him. Maria writ The letter, at Sir Toby's great importance, In recompense whereof he hath married her. How with a sportful malice it was follow'd May rather pluck on laughter than revenge, If that the injuries be justly weigh'd That have on both sides passed.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: Alas, poor fool, how have they baffled thee!

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Why, ‘some are born great, some achieve greatness, and some have greatness thrown upon them.' I was one, sir, in this interlude, one Sir Topas, sir, but that's all one. ‘By the Lord, fool, I am not mad.' But do you remember? ‘Madam, why laugh you at such a barren rascal? And you smile not, he's gagged'? And thus the whirligig of time brings in his revenges.

dialogues.speaker: Malvolio
dialogues.line: I'll be revenged on the whole pack of you.

dialogues.speaker: Olivia
dialogues.line: He hath been most notoriously abus'd.

dialogues.speaker: Duke
dialogues.line: Pursue him, and entreat him to a peace: He hath not told us of the captain yet. When that is known, and golden time convents, A solemn combination shall be made Of our dear souls.-Meantime, sweet sister, We will not part from hence.-Cesario, come: For so you shall be while you are a man; But when in other habits you are seen, Orsino's mistress, and his fancy's queen. Clown sings. _   When that I was and a little tiny boy, With hey, ho, the wind and the rain, A foolish thing was but a toy, For the rain it raineth every day._ _   But when I came to man's estate, With hey, ho, the wind and the rain, 'Gainst knaves and thieves men shut their gate, For the rain it raineth every day._ _   But when I came, alas, to wive, With hey, ho, the wind and the rain, By swaggering could I never thrive, For the rain it raineth every day._ _   But when I came unto my beds, With hey, ho, the wind and the rain, With toss-pots still had drunken heads, For the rain it raineth every day._ _   A great while ago the world begun, With hey, ho, the wind and the rain, But that's all one, our play is done, And we'll strive to please you every day._
